Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Mathematics Mentoring and Scholarship (MMS) program at the University of the Incarnate Word (UIW) in San Antonio Texas will increase the number of academically talented but financially needy students qualified to enter the STEM workforce or graduate school upon completing a bachelor's degree in mathematics. The program will provide annual scholarships to 15 mathematics majors along with funds for travel for professional development and to conduct academic presentations. Students will participate in weekly mentoring sessions to address any issues concerning their courses, degree, and college experience. Recruitment will target local high schools and five local community colleges in the Alamo Colleges network. This project will increase the number of academically talented but financially needy students qualified to enter graduate school in mathematics or to enter the workforce in a technical area of national need that requires professionals with advanced mathematics knowledge.

The objectives of the program are to increase student retention and graduation and to ensure participation in mentoring and professional development activities. The program also encourages student participation in research programs and/or internships to facilitate placement of in a technical field or graduate program. Scholars in the program will be paired with a peer to guide them through issues or concerns they have regarding university life, the mathematics degree, and other program related issues. Field trips to local employers will expose students to real-world STEM experiences and provide them with potential employment opportunities. The MMS program has the potential to increase the number of woman and underrepresented groups available to purse STEM related graduate degrees or employment and to develop effective academic interventions to support these groups.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Mathematics Mentoring and Scholarship (MMS) program at the University of the Incarnate Word (UIW) in San Antonio Texas provided support for academically talented but financially needy students qualified to enter the STEM workforce or graduate school upon completing a bachelor's degree in mathematics and statistics. MMS program provided support and scholarship to 33 students. The program offered weekly mentoring sessions to address students’ challenges and open up opportunities for their future careers.

The retention rate of the MMS scholars is %81, and 6% of scholars left the program because they were not financially needy anymore. But that 6% of scholars graduated successfully during the grant period. Including the 6%, retention rate would be 86%.  Among MMS scholars, the graduation rate during the grant period is 64%, 12% left the program, and 24% are currently students in Mathematics and Statistics program. Under representative group in the MMS program is 66% (female scholars). 84 % of graduates placed in a technical job or the graduate program in STEM.

Other than providing scholarship, the MMS program also had various professional development and service activities to scholars such as weekly mentoring sessions, invited speakers from government, industry, and academia, conference travels, career service presentations and career service visits, applications to graduate school, game night and social events, technical skills seminars, applying to summer research programs and internships workshops, community service events. 92% of scholars participated in the weekly Scholar Mentoring Sessions with faculty members. The scholars 87% participated in the Mathematics Scholar Group Activities which included a conference, off-campus trips, and guest presentations. Peer mentoring is an important part of the program and 90% participated in the Mathematics Peer Mentoring Program.

Each year average of 8 scholars applied for summer undergraduate research experience and internship opportunities. Scholars also presented their research at local and national conferences.

UIW requires 40 hours of community service for undergraduate students. MMS scholars participated in various community service activities including volunteer at San Antonio Food Bank, painting houses and doing neighborhood cleanup, volunteering for Cardinal Math Circle for middle school students, participate in and contribute to organizing the annual UIW Meet the Mission Day (day of community service).

Scholars participated in at least two conferences annually, one in the fall primarily for undergraduate math conference and in the spring MAA Texas Sectional meetings. Conference travels and social gatherings helped to build community among scholars and faculty members. Some scholars also participated Joint Mathematics Meeting and Filed of Dreams Conference.

Scholars participated in different career seminars and workshops including writing resume/curriculum vitae, cover letter, personal statement, building LinkedIn page, mock interviews, professional attire, presentation skills, invited speakers from diverse careers, participating in STEM career fairs organized by Pi and Co-PIs and UIW career Center.
